section.title: Installation of Ruby on Rails 3.2 with RVM on Mac OS X 10.7
section.para: The number of Ruby on Rails developers who use Mac OS X is encouragingly high. On Rails conferences, you usually see around 80 % of participants with a MacBook.

Mac OS 10.7 includes Ruby version 1.8.7 as standard. Not interesting for our purposes. We want Ruby 1.9.3 and Rails 3.2. To avoid interfering with the existing Ruby and Rails installation and therefore the packet management of Mac OS X, we install Ruby 1.9.3 and Rails 3.2 with RVM
Ruby Version Manager RVM (Ruby Version Manager).

With RVM, you can install and run any number of Ruby and Rails versions as normal user (without root rights and in your home directory). So you can work in parallel on old projects that may still use Ruby 1.8.7 and new projects that use Ruby 1.9.3.

note.para: Detailled information on RVM can be found at the RVM homepage at https://rvm.io/.

warning.para: If you are reading the printed book version of this chapter, please check the online version at http://www.ruby-auf-schienen.de. Each update of the operating system or RVM also usually involves an update of the installation instructions.

section.title: Xcode Installation or Upgrade
section.para: Before you start installing Ruby on Rails, you must install the latest Apple Xcode tools on your system. The easiest way is via the Mac App Store (search for "xcode") or via the website https://developer.apple.com/xcode/.

section.title: Installing Ruby 1.9.3 with RVM
section.para: Open a terminal with your normal user rights and check which Ruby version is installed:MacBook:~ xyz$ ruby -v ruby 1.8.7 (2011-12-28 patchlevel 357) [universal-darwin11.0] MacBook:~ xyz$

RVM can be installed in various ways. I recommend using the following monster command (please copy it exactly) that installs the latest RVM:MacBook:~ xyz$ curl -L https://get.rvm.io | bash -s stable % Total % Received % Xferd Average Speed Time Time Time Current Dload Upload Total Spent Left Speed 100 9439 100 9439 0 0 8337 0 0:00:01 0:00:01 --:--:-- 69918 Downloading RVM from wayneeseguin branch stable % Total % Received % Xferd Average Speed Time Time Time Current Dload Upload Total Spent Left Speed 100 1046k 100 1046k 0 0 257k 0 0:00:04 0:00:04 --:--:-- 417k

Installation of RVM in /Users/xyz/.rvm/ is almost complete:
* To start using RVM you need to run `source /Users/xyz/.rvm/scripts/rvm` in all your open shell windows, in rare cases you need to reopen all shell windows.
# xyz, # # Thank you for using RVM! # I sincerely hope that RVM helps to make your life easier and more enjoyable!!! # # ~Wayne
rvm 1.14.5 (stable) by Wayne E. Seguin <wayneeseguin@gmail.com>, Michal Papis <mpapis@gmail.com> [https://rvm.io/]
MacBook:~ xyz$
RVM is now installed. You can now either close your terminal window (and therefore your active shell) or load the required parameters as follows:

To test if rvm is correctly installed, let's try calling it with -v:MacBook:~ xyz$ rvm -v
rvm 1.14.5 (stable) by Wayne E. Seguin <wayneeseguin@gmail.com>, Michal Papis <mpapis@gmail.com> [https://rvm.io/]
MacBook:~ xyz$
If you should get the bash command not found as reply, you need to check the above steps again. You probably accidentally skipped a step (for example, forgot to reopen the terminal).

RVM changes the default Ruby directly to the version you just installed:MacBook:~ xyz$ ruby -v ruby 1.9.3p194 (2012-04-20 revision 35410) [x86_64-darwin11.4.0] MacBook:~ xyz$

note.para: With the command rvm system you can switch back to the system Ruby version 1.8.x any time.

tip.para: You can enter the command rvm to display a corresponding help page with further available commands.

section.title: Generate Ruby Documentation
section.para: Ruby has an integrated and constantly accessible documentation (see ). If you want to install this (and I highly recommend you do), you now need to start rvm docs generate: MacBook:~ xyz$ rvm docs generate Generating ri documentation, be aware that this could take a *long* time, and depends heavily on your system resources... ( Errors will be logged to /Users/xyz/.rvm/log/ruby-1.9.3-p194/docs.log ) Generating rdoc documentation, be aware that this could take a *long* time, and depends heavily on your system resources... ( Errors will be logged to /Users/xyz/.rvm/log/ruby-1.9.3-p194/docs.log ) MacBook:~ xyz$

section.title: Installing Rails
section.para: First, we check if Ruby opens in version 1.9.3. If this is not the case, please read .MacBook:~ xyz$ ruby -v ruby 1.9.3p194 (2012-04-20 revision 35410) [x86_64-darwin11.4.0] MacBook:~ xyz$Then we make sure that the gem package management is up to date:MacBook:~ xyz$ gem update Updating installed gems Nothing to update MacBook:~ xyz$

section.title: Installing Rails 3.2
section.para:
The rest is easy:MacBook:~ xyz$ gem install rails --version '~> 3.2.0' Fetching: i18n-0.6.0.gem (100%) Fetching: multi_json-1.3.2.gem (100%)
[...]
Installing RDoc documentation for railties-3.2.7... Installing RDoc documentation for rails-3.2.7... MacBook:~ xyz$
Perfect. You have now installed Rails 3.2. MacBook:~ xyz$ rails -v Rails 3.2.7 MacBook:~ xyz$

note.para: If you want to install an older Rails version one day, you can edit the parameter --version and insert the corresponding older version number (for example --version '~> 3.1.0' for the most current Rails 3.1 version).
